Caption:
LE DONNE GIRAFFA
KAREN LONG NECK VILLAGE 
Chiang Rai 

I Kayan sono una etnia della popolazione Karenni, una minoranza di lingua tibeto-birmana. Sono anche chiamati Padaung, che nella lingua autoctona significa "collo lungo". Nel 1990 a causa di un conflitto con il regime militare birmano, molte tribÃ¹ si sono rifugiate nella vicina Thailandia. Da allora esse vivono con uno status legale incerto nei villaggi di confine, ma sopravvivono soprattutto grazie ai proventi derivati dal turismo, per via della tipica spirale di ottone che le donne Kayan indossano al collo fin dalla tenera etÃ . Si stima che la popolazione kayana ammonti a circa settemila membri di ambo i sessi.
In Italia le donne della tribÃ¹ Kayan sono conosciute con questo nome, dovuto alle modifiche fisiche provocate dalla caratteristica spirale di ottone indossata fin dall'infanzia, a partire dall'etÃ  di cinque anni. Crescendo, la spirale viene ciclicamente sostituita con altre di dimensioni sempre maggiori, fino a che la sua pressione esercitata sul corpo non provoca un progressivo slittamento della clavicola e una conseguente compressione della gabbia toracica. Pertanto, diversamente da quanto ritenuto, non Ã¨ il collo a subire un allungamento, bensÃ¬ le spalle a scendere. L'illusione ottica Ã¨ creata dalla deformazione della clavicola, soprattutto nei soggetti piÃ¹ anziani, dove le spirali di ottone possono contare fino a venticinque anelli. Nessuna donna Kayan si priva di questa spirale ornamentale per tutta la propria esistenza, tranne in caso di adulterio. Una pena resa ancora piÃ¹ pesante laddove la donna, se privata della propria spirale, sarebbe costretta a vivere perennemente sdraiata come un'invalida, perchÃ¨ gli anelli in ottone nel collo portano all'atrofizzazione delle vertebre cervicali al punto che la donna non sarebbe piÃ¹ in grado di reggere la testa se la collana viene tolta.

Caption: I went to Shangqiu in Eastern Henan Province to study tea. Shangqiu was the capital during the Shang Dynasty. We visited the ancient city and Yingtian Academy.  This is one of the 4 great ancient academies during the Northern Song Dynasty. Confucianism was taught during this time. I had visited the Imperial College in Beijing that was the top of the 4 great academies. The beautiful lady in the picture with me is the professional artist that did my make-up, hair, and costume to reflect a noble woman of the Song Dynasty. It was considered the romance period of the Chinese Dynasties. She explained in detail how and why they used certain make-up and hair ornaments. She specializes in historical costuming and make-up. It was a fun experience!  #txgirlinchina #mylifeinchina #mychinatravels #shangqiu #henanprovince #songdynasty #yingtianacademy #confucianism
Hashtags: henanprovince, txgirlinchina, mychinatravels, confucianism, yingtianacademy, shangqiu, songdynasty, mylifeinchina

She also provides an epilogue discussing the changes in contemporary China that will shape the nation in the years to come."

Pingyao or Ping Yao is a county located in Shanxi province, China, about 700 kilometers from Beijing. During the Qing Dynasty, Pingyao Old City was the financial center of China. It is famous for its excellently preserved walls; it has also been included in the list of UNESCO World Heritage Sites. Pingyao largely retains the organization and appearance of a city from the Ming and Qing dynasties.

Pingyao or Ping Yao is a county located in Shanxi province, China, about 700 kilometers from Beijing. During the Qing Dynasty, Pingyao Old City was the financial center of China. It is famous for its excellently preserved walls; it has also been included in the list of UNESCO World Heritage Sites. Pingyao largely retains the organization and appearance of a city from the Ming and Qing dynasties.

Caption:
Minggu, 05 Mei 2024 - Sharing bareng Prof. Anna Sun (Associate Professor of Religious Studies, Duke University, US) mengenai pandangan Ajaran Konfusianisme sebagai salah satu Agama di Dunia di litang kesayangan kita Klenteng Pak Kik Bio- Hian Thian Siang Tee, Jagalan berjalan dengan baik dan lancar.

Terima kasih kepada segenap umat, pengurus, rohaniwan, panitia dan para tamu undangan yang sudah menyempatkan waktu untuk menghadiri dan mensukseskan acara ini.

Yang bikin semangat, ternyata tamu undangan kita tidak hanya dari Surabaya lho (Pak Kik Bio, Boen Bio, Sam Poo Kong)..
Audiens yang hadir juga dari Klenteng Bojonegoro, Mojokerto, Pasuruan, Sidoarjo, Krian dan Malang.

Yang ga mau ketinggalan keseruan acara sharing kemarin, bisa banget nonton lagi di IG/Youtube live yang sudah kita posting di feed sebelumnya...

Sampai jumpa di acara menarik kita berikutnya, kiranya Tian memberkati kita semua, Shanzai ğŸ™ğŸ»

Caption:
Sungyang Hall is a fourteenth-century Confucian academy located on the side of Mt. Janam in Kaesong, North Korea. 

The hall was constructed in the late 14th century for the home of the famously loyal statesman and Confucian scholar Jong Mong-ju, whose 1392 assassination by the agents of the later Taejo of Joseon marked the end of the Koryo dynasty. 

In 1573, the building was transformed into a Confucian academy. 

Photo Credit: Kuanping Lin

Year: 2013

The May Fourth Movement (Chinese: äº”å››è¿åŠ¨) was a Chinese social movement, arising from student protests in front of Tiananmen Gate in Beijing on May 4, 1919.

The young people demonstrated against a government that they considered weak and controlled by foreign powers. They also chanted slogans in favor of democracy and science, and against tradition and Confucianism.

Caption:
"What the gentleman seeks in himself the small man seeks in others" -Confucius

I finished reading 'The Analects' by Confucius a few days ago and I really enjoyed it. To me personally most of the things that Confucius said seemed like common sense, but I had to really look at the contents of the book through the lens of the time it was written. It reminded me greatly of 'The Art of War' which is very good, but it's telling you, for the most part, very basic things. Things like 'prolonged wars are bad for the economy' or 'use supplies from your enemies so you can save your own supplies'. Now this seems very basic to me, and to many people in our day and age. However back in the time it was written this stuff was revolutionary and gave everyone an insight of how war works. I feel the same way about 'The Analects' it was groundbreaking and revolutionized China's culture at the time when it was written around 200 BC. It is an incredibly beautiful and helpful book that gives you clear paths of improvement and self satisfaction, but when I read it, it felt more like a reminder of all of these things than an introduction. I absolutely did adore this book, and I love books that are similar to it that offer these nuggets of wisdom, I just like to think about the implications these types of books have today then they did when they were originally written.

Caption:
Ngoc Son Temple is famous in Hanoi as it not only features the traditional architecture & the spiritual life of the Vietnamese people but alsoÂ a good view of the famous Hoan Kiem Lake. It is a sacred site where people come to pray for good fortune & for peace of mind. 

It worships Van Xuong De Quan (Wenchang Dijun), a Taoist deity that brings happiness and wealth to scholars. It is also dedicated to General Tran Hung Dao (1231 - 1300), who defeated the Mongols in the 13th century.

Nghi Mon Gate is the entrance to the complex, with 2 columns and walls engraved with Chinese letters on both sides - pic 2

Stepping inside, you can see Pen Tower on the left. The tower was constructed atop a stone hill in 1865. It is 28 meters tall and has a stone feather pen on top. Carved on the tower are 3 Chinese letters â€œTa Thanh Thienâ€, meaning "Write onto the sky" - pic 3

The Huc BridgeÂ is regarded as a symbol of the Sun God, its name meaning â€œwhere sunlight beams in early morningâ€ - pic 1, 4 & 5

For more pictures, see @the_centauride
.
.

Caption:
IL MONASTERO SOSPESO DI DATONG â€“ THE HANGING TEMPLE OF DATONG 

Il Monastero Sospeso di Datong o Tempio Xuankong Ã¨ un tempio costruito su una rupe a 75 metri di altezza, vicino al Monte Heng, nella provincia cinese dello Shanxi. Insieme alle grotte di Yungang Ã¨ una delle maggiori attrazioni turistiche della zona. Costruito nella prima metÃ  del primo millennio, deve il suo valore non solo alla posizione, ma anche al fatto che Ã¨ il solo esempio di tempio dove si combinano le tre religioni tradizionali cinesi: buddismo, taoismo e confucianesimo. 

Hengshan Hanging Temple/Monastery (built in 491 A.D. by a monk named Liaoran) is a temple built into a cliff (75 m or 246 ft above the ground) near Mount Heng in Hunyuan County, Datong City, Shanxi Province, China. The closest city is Datong, 64 kilometres (40 mi) to the northwest. Along with the Yungang Grottoes, the Hanging Temple is one of the main tourist attractions and historical sites in the Datong area. Built more than 1,500 years ago, this temple is notable not only for its location on a sheer precipice but also because as a Buddhist temple it also contains references to the other two of the three Chinese traditional philosophies or religions: Taoism, and Confucianism. The structure is kept in place with oak crossbeams fitted into holes chiseled into the cliffs. The main supportive structure is hidden inside the bedrock. The monastery is located in the small canyon basin, and the body of the building hangs from the middle of the cliff under the prominent summit, protecting the temple from rain erosion and sunlight bake.
